caption: An absolutely delightful experience. From buying an entrance ticket, through to each floor of the exhibition to the exit.  The staff at the main desk had a lot of information about the exhibits and the local area. All in all an amazing day out x
Lovely, intimate gallery...go, and take in the temporary exhibits as well.

The sculptures of Landowski are amazing. Checking out the rest of the museum is also worth while if you are there, but in my view it would not justify a visit by itself. Anyhow, if you are at Boulogne-Billancourt, you should definetively visit the museum.

One of my favorite museums here in Paris. It's a bit off the beaten path, and it can take a while to get there, but it's worth it, especially if you have an interest in this era.  They really have a very nice collection. The furniture and decor is mostly a miss, but the paintings and sculptures are excellent.  Very interesting special exhibits, too.  The place was almost empty when I went (free first Sunday of the month), so I had plenty of room to admire the art.  Oh and the staff are super friendly.

If you're visiting Paris and want to do something off the beaten track,  I recommend a walk around Boulogne-Billancourt and a visit to the 1930s Museum. It has an excellent collection of 1930s furniture  and archectural models. After your visit you can go and see some of the models in real life in the streets of the neighbourhood.

This is a collection located at the top floor of Espace Landowski. The 7 euro ticket gives you access to all the exhibitions in the complex, which focus on the early 20th century arts in all forms. If you're interested in art déco, it's well worth the visit.
Well worth a visit. Pleasant welcome, well structured and informative. And great works of art!
The tickets to the museum are not longer sold after 17:30 if you’re going there plan to get ahead of time and don’t depend on the tome shown on the website which is 18:00
Top quality display of very special items ranging from paintings to sculptures and furniture. Gorgeous collection in a pristine setting.

If you are intrerested in Art Deco, this museum is a little jem. It helps a lot if you understand a little French. Until 10 February 2020 you can see the exhibition about the ocean liner Isle de France. It has some info in English. You can also see furniture, paintings and sculptures from the era between the world wars. There is also a large section devoted to the Paris school art movement. Architecturally Boulogne-Billancourt is interesting with a lot of art deco style buildings.
Stunning local museum tells the story of Boulogne in the 30s. Beautiful exhibits from art to furniture. Very nice way to learn about history from the last century.
The museum is small but nice. It has a life-size statue of Sun Yat-sen among other arts. I enjoyed visiting this museum.
Small, but well curated, single admission with other small collections in the building
Interesting
Delightful small museum, mostly dedicated to early 20th century art
Very varied exhibitions. Well worth a visit. Takes a couple of hours. Good value.
Beautiful museum with amazing sculpture, furniture and paintings. I loved it!
Small museum but worth the visit, I found the exposition about the colonial arts particularly interesting.
Not bad although I expected more designer objects, rather than fine arts
An unusual museum focused on the 1930s and Art Deco
One of the finest galleries in France imo
Very nice and underrated.
A mixture of furniture, sculptures and paintings.
Great place to visit
Excellent !

A museum where you can dive into the interwar period, when various art trends such as Art Deco, Cubism, and Neoclassicism flourished. Recommended for those who like the atmosphere of the movie Midnight in Paris. The collection is quite large, spread over 4 floors. Navigo Pass or Louvre annual membership holders receive discounted admission, and the first Sunday of each month is free.
Very beautiful museum representative of the 1930s in architecture, sculpture, painting, furniture. Very well organized and explained. I recommend
Nestled in the Boulogne Billancourt media library, a museum with very beautiful pieces dating from the 20s and 30s. A great discovery.

It is very rare that I find so much pleasure in discovering a museum. This was the case here. My friend had discovered this wonder and suggested we go there. I had little apprehension because the period fascinates me. I really loved it. The building is already a success in itself and the layout of the different levels is very well organized. The furniture section was fascinating and the section devoted to pieces from the colonial exhibitions contains some truly magnificent pieces. Apart from the temperatures being a little too high on the top floor (I sincerely pity the staff who monitor the premises) everything was perfect.

My friend and I have just discovered this very beautiful museum located in the Boulogne media library very close to the town hall.  This museum clearly deserves to be better known. I'm sure there would be more visitors if it was right in the center of Paris. However, you can get there easily by car or even by taking metro line 1. We were delighted by our recent visit even if we were surprised to be the only ones wandering around the museum. We were dazzled by the collections spread over 3 floors: the very beautiful paintings, the sculptures, the reconstructions of apartment interiors and the furniture. The part that fascinated us the most was the one devoted to orientalism and artists from the colonial era. Too bad the museum is overheated. This can dampen the pleasure of the visit.

A great discovery, this museum is full of lovely surprises in both painting and sculpture. Obviously less publicized than the neighboring Parisian museums, it is worth the detour for a small price which also allows you to also discover the interesting Paul-Landowski museum.
Bright, rich, varied, it deserves to be known.
Very nice museum and a hidden gem! The Landowski Museum and the Museum of the Thirties were a discovery. Furthermore, very friendly staff, beautiful images and period furniture. You must see.
Nice little museum.  Too bad their store is so small. I wanted postcards of the pieces that I liked. Visit of approximately 1h30.
Very beautiful museum on 3 floors with elevator. School of Paris, colonial art, sacred art, space dedicated to Paul Landowski. You can easily stay there for 2 hours.

Not too well known museum (I think), but really a hidden treasure. Very affordable price for a very large collection. Lots of works by well-known artists from the 30s. The lady at reception is extremely polite and friendly. She warned me that it would be hot upstairs and helped me put down my bag and coat.
Very nice museum with interesting works. Allows you to better understand the artistic movement of this era as well as the artist Paul Landowski.
Very complete museum and the welcome is excellent.
